column4: Scrutiny in Tameside

column1: To find out what is currently happening in Scrutiny
<table cellpadding="5" width="100%" summary="Summaries of Scrutiny and how it works in Tameside" border="1">

"Overview and Scrutiny in Tameside is positive, objective and constructive, it aims to add value to any service that it considers. It acknowledges good practice and recommends improvements where necessary. Scrutiny seeks to engage the community of Tameside and address inequalities in the Borough"
The Local Government Act 2000 requires all councils in England and Wales to introduce new political structures which provide a clear role for the Council, the Executive and non executive councillors.

One of the key roles for non executive councillors is to undertake an overview and scrutiny role for the Council. The overview and scrutiny role involves reviewing policies of the Council, helping to develop policies for the Council, involvement with best value reviews, scrutinising organisations external to the Council and holding the Executive to account.
How does Scrutiny Operate in Tameside?

In Tameside there is a strong scrutiny function led by non executive councillors, independent from the Cabinet. Scrutiny in Tameside has a positive and constructive ethos, which aims to improve services to the public by scrutinising the policies of the Council and how those policies are put into practice.

In Tameside overview and scrutiny operates through four scrutiny panels. Scrutiny panels meet in public at least once a month, usually at the Council Offices, Wellington Road, Ashton-under-Lyne. They comprise non executive councillors, some co-opted members and people who have experience or knowledge of the subject under consideration.

Scrutiny panels each have their own annual work programme, which is decided by the panel members and published on this web site and in the local press. The work programmes are devised following extensive consultation and include suggestions from members of the public.
In carrying out scrutiny exercises, members of scrutiny panels go out and informally visit people who carry out services or can provide information, as well as interviewing people in formal meetings.
'What To Do When Attending a Scrutiny Panel' 185.83 KB A helpsheet if you are unsure what to expect ..
Scrutiny Panels produce reports of their findings and these are presented by the respective Chairs to the Council and discussed at Council meetings.

Scrutiny Panel reports acknowledge good practice and where necessary recommend improvements to services. After a suitable period to allow for the implementation of recommendations, scrutiny panel reports are reviewed by panel members to find out whether recommendations have been put into practice, and if there have been improvements for service users.
These reports are available on this website at public libraries, Council Offices and can be viewed on the Centre for Public Scrutiny's website at www.cfps.org.uk
The Scrutiny Panels also publish annual reports, these can be viewed via the following links:

During the Personal and Health Services Scrutiny Panel's Review of Disabled Facilities in Town Centres, a Disability Etiquette was formulated to help identify and avoid inappropriate language and behaviour towards people with disabilities. This is not just pertinent to this review, but should be embraced by everyone. Please consult the disability etiquette page for the complete document.
How can people know what is happening in Scrutiny?

Scrutiny panels actively welcome involvement with the public and seek the views of members of the public on services that are being considered. Scrutiny panels also welcome suggestions for subjects to be considered for inclusion in the scrutiny work programme.
Overview and Scrutiny is not a complaints system - there is a separate Corporate Complaints System for use by members of the public.

Everything relating to the overview and scrutiny function in Tameside can be found on this web site, from panel agendas and minutes, terms of reference and protocols, right through to detailed scoping documents for each scrutiny exercise and scrutiny reports themselves.

The Scrutiny Support Unit has prepared standards for service delivery, which form part of our performance indicators. We also send out annual customer surveys to all Members of Scrutiny Panels and assessment and feedback forms to all people who attend Scrutiny Panels. We have full details and how we are using the analysis to improve our service.

Each scrutiny panel is assisted by the Scrutiny Support Unit and each panel has its own dedicated Scrutiny Support Officer who undertakes research, organises consultation and briefs panel members with relevant information. Panels are also supported by dedicated Scrutiny Panel Co-ordinators who organise meetings, prepare agendas and minutes, invite people to attend meetings and take a lead in drafting panel reports.
